Ayam Goreng.description: Ayam Goreng is Indonesian fried chicken, marinated with spices then deep-fried until golden.
Ayam Goreng.culture_events: Common everyday dish, served with rice and sambal.

tips.spice_level: Mild to medium; sambal can add heat

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Ayam goreng, satu porsi' (One portion of fried chicken).

Ayam Goreng.fun_fact: Every region in Indonesia has its own twist on Ayam Goreng spices.

Ayam Pop.description: Ayam Pop is a Padang-style fried chicken, boiled briefly in coconut water before frying, resulting in tender, pale chicken.
Ayam Pop.culture_events: Served in Padang restaurants, usually with sambal and rice.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Ayam pop, satu porsi' (One portion of Ayam Pop).

Ayam Pop.fun_fact: Ayam Pop looks pale because it’s briefly boiled in coconut water before frying.

Bakso.taste: savory, umami; sometimes spicy with sambal
Bakso.description: Bakso is Indonesian meatball soup, served with noodles, tofu, and vegetables. Popular street food throughout Indonesia.
Bakso.culture_events: Eaten as affordable everyday meal; common from street carts and casual restaurants.

tips.spice_level: Adjustable with sambal; mild recommended for first-timers.
tips.halal: Usually halal; ask vendor if unsure.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Saya mau bakso satu mangkok' (One bowl of bakso).
tourist_notes.safety: Choose busy stalls; fresh hot soup is safer.

Bakso.fun_fact: Bakso is bouncy due to tapioca flour; compared to Italian meatballs, it’s served in broth and eaten with noodles.

Bakwan.description: Bakwan is Indonesian vegetable fritters, deep-fried and crunchy, commonly served as snack or side dish.
Bakwan.culture_events: Popular street snack and side for meals.

tips.spice_level: Mild; usually eaten with chili sauce

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Bakwan, satu porsi' (One portion of Bakwan).
tourist_notes.safety: Eat freshly fried for best taste

Bakwan.fun_fact: Bakwan is sometimes mixed with corn, carrots, or shrimp.

Batagor.description: Batagor is fried fish dumplings served with peanut sauce, a famous Bandung street snack.
Batagor.culture_events: Often eaten as snack or appetizer.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Batagor, satu porsi' (One portion of Batagor).

Batagor.fun_fact: Batagor literally stands for 'Bakso Tahu Goreng' (Fried Tofu and Fish Balls).

Bubur.description: Bubur is rice porridge, eaten for breakfast or when sick, often served with chicken, egg, or shredded fish.

tips.spice_level: Usually mild; toppings can add flavor

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Bubur ayam, satu porsi' (One portion of rice porridge with chicken).

Bubur.fun_fact: Bubur is a traditional comfort food in Indonesia, similar to congee in other Asian countries.

Burger.origin: Western origin, widely available in Indonesia
Burger.description: Burger is a Western fast food, popular in Indonesia with local adaptations.
Burger.culture_events: Eaten as fast food or snack; available in cafes and restaurants.

tips.spice_level: Mild to medium depending on toppings

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Burger, satu porsi' (One burger).

Burger.fun_fact: Indonesian burgers often include local flavors like sambal or fried egg.

Cakwe.taste: crispy outside, soft inside; mildly savory
Cakwe.description: Cakwe are deep-fried dough sticks, often eaten for breakfast or as snack with soy milk.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Cakwe, satu porsi' (One portion of cakwe).
tourist_notes.safety: Eat freshly fried for best taste

Cakwe.fun_fact: Cakwe is usually dipped in soy sauce or eaten with porridge.

Capcay.description: Capcay is a stir-fried vegetable dish often served with protein like chicken, shrimp, or fish.
Capcay.culture_events: Common side dish in family meals and Chinese-Indonesian restaurants.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Capcay, satu porsi' (One portion of Capcay).

Capcay.fun_fact: Capcay literally means 'mixed vegetables' in Hokkien Chinese.

Crepes.taste: sweet or savory depending on filling
Crepes.description: Crepes are thin pancakes that can be filled with sweet chocolate, fruit, or savory meat and cheese.
Crepes.culture_events: Popular street snack and dessert, especially in cafes or night markets.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Crepes, satu porsi' (One portion of crepes).

Crepes.fun_fact: Indonesian crepes sometimes include local toppings like jackfruit or chocolate sprinkles.

Dendeng Batokok.description: Dendeng Batokok is thinly sliced beef fried with spices, sometimes pounded to make it tender.
Dendeng Batokok.culture_events: Served in Padang restaurants, often as side dish to rice.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Dendeng Batokok, satu porsi' (One portion of Dendeng Batokok).

Dendeng Batokok.fun_fact: The name 'Batokok' comes from pounding the meat thin before frying.

Fu Yung Hai.description: Fu Yung Hai is an Indonesian-Chinese omelet with vegetables and meat or seafood, often served with sauce.
Fu Yung Hai.culture_events: Common in family meals and Chinese-Indonesian restaurants.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Fu Yung Hai, satu porsi' (One portion of Fu Yung Hai).

Fu Yung Hai.fun_fact: Fu Yung Hai means 'egg flower' in Chinese, referring to the fluffy omelet.

Gado-Gado.description: Gado-Gado is an Indonesian salad of blanched vegetables with peanut sauce, often served with rice cakes.
Gado-Gado.culture_events: Common street food and home dish.

tips.spice_level: Mild to medium; can add chili

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Gado-gado, satu porsi' (One portion of Gado-Gado).

Gado-Gado.fun_fact: Gado-Gado literally means 'mix-mix', referring to the variety of ingredients.

Gudeg.description: Gudeg is a traditional Javanese dish made from young jackfruit stewed in coconut milk and palm sugar.
Gudeg.culture_events: Often eaten for breakfast with rice, chicken, and sambal krecek; iconic Yogyakarta food.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Gudeg, satu porsi' (One portion of Gudeg).

Gudeg.fun_fact: Gudeg can take several hours to cook until the jackfruit is tender and flavorful.

Gulai Ikan.description: Gulai Ikan is a fish curry cooked in coconut milk with aromatic spices.
Gulai Ikan.culture_events: Common in coastal areas and traditional ceremonies.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Gulai Ikan, satu porsi' (One portion of fish curry).

Gulai Ikan.fun_fact: The word 'Gulai' refers to a type of curry with rich spices and coconut milk.

Gulai Tambusu.description: Gulai Tambusu is cow intestine stuffed with spicy meat mixture and cooked in coconut milk curry.
Gulai Tambusu.culture_events: Traditional Makassar dish; often eaten during gatherings.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Gulai Tambusu, satu porsi'.
tourist_notes.safety: Eat freshly cooked; ensure intestines are properly cleaned

Gulai Tunjang.description: Gulai Tunjang is beef tendon cooked in rich spicy coconut milk curry.
Gulai Tunjang.culture_events: Often served in Padang restaurants; considered a delicacy.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Gulai Tunjang, satu porsi'.

Gulai Tunjang.fun_fact: Tendon becomes gelatinous when slow-cooked in coconut milk curry.

Gyoza.description: Gyoza are Japanese dumplings often fried or steamed, served with dipping sauce.
Gyoza.culture_events: Available in Japanese restaurants and street stalls in Indonesia.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Gyoza, satu porsi'.

Gyoza.fun_fact: Gyoza in Indonesia may have local fillings like chicken or prawn.

Ikan.description: Ikan refers to fish; can be grilled, fried, or in curries.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Ikan, satu porsi'.

Ikan.fun_fact: Indonesian cuisine includes various fish species, often grilled with sambal.

Ikan Goreng.description: Fried fish, usually seasoned with turmeric and salt, served with sambal and rice.
Ikan Goreng.culture_events: Common in households and restaurants; daily meal.

tips.spice_level: Mild to medium if sambal added

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Ikan Goreng, satu porsi'.

Ikan Goreng.fun_fact: Simple but very popular street food in Indonesia.

Kebab.description: Kebab is grilled meat with spices, served in bread or as wrap, popular street food in Indonesia.
Kebab.culture_events: Found in street stalls, food courts, and Middle Eastern restaurants.

tips.spice_level: Mild to spicy depending on sauce

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Kebab, satu porsi' (One kebab).

Kebab.fun_fact: Indonesian kebabs often include local sambal or chili sauce.

Kelepon.description: Kelepon are sweet rice cakes filled with liquid palm sugar, coated in grated coconut.
Kelepon.culture_events: Traditional snack served during gatherings and ceremonies.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Kelepon, satu porsi' (One portion of Kelepon).

Kelepon.fun_fact: Kelepon has a liquid palm sugar center that bursts in your mouth when eaten.

Kerupuk.description: Kerupuk are Indonesian crackers, often served as snack or side dish with meals.
Kerupuk.culture_events: Popular in daily meals and traditional celebrations.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Kerupuk, satu porsi' (One portion of crackers).

Kerupuk.fun_fact: Kerupuk are often deep-fried just before eating to retain crispiness.

Mie Goreng.description: Mie Goreng is Indonesian fried noodles, commonly stir-fried with vegetables, eggs, and protein.
Mie Goreng.culture_events: Popular street food, breakfast or dinner dish.

tips.spice_level: Mild to spicy depending on chili

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Mie Goreng, satu porsi'.

Mie Goreng.fun_fact: Mie Goreng is a popular comfort food across Indonesia and often customized with local flavors.

Nasi Goreng.description: Nasi Goreng is Indonesian fried rice, often topped with fried egg and served with crackers.
Nasi Goreng.culture_events: National dish, eaten for any meal; street food and restaurants.

tips.spice_level: Mild to spicy depending on chili

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Nasi Goreng, satu porsi'.

Nasi Goreng.fun_fact: Nasi Goreng is often served with pickles, prawn crackers, and a fried egg on top.

Nasi Padang.description: Nasi Padang is steamed rice served with various dishes from Padang cuisine.
Nasi Padang.culture_events: Padang restaurants display dishes buffet-style; pay for what you eat.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Nasi Padang, satu porsi'.

Nasi Padang.fun_fact: Paying only for the dishes you eat is unique to Nasi Padang culture.

Onion Rings.description: Onion rings are sliced onions coated in batter and fried until crispy.
Onion Rings.culture_events: Popular snack or side dish in fast-food and cafes.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Onion Rings, satu porsi'.

Onion Rings.fun_fact: Onion rings are a favorite side snack with burgers in Indonesia.

Rawon.description: Rawon is a traditional beef soup with dark black broth from kluwek nuts.
Rawon.culture_events: Served as daily meal or special occasions in East Java.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Rawon, satu porsi'.

Rawon.fun_fact: The black color comes from the kluwek seed, giving Rawon its unique flavor.

Rendang.description: Rendang is slow-cooked beef in coconut milk and a mixture of rich spices.
Rendang.culture_events: Traditional dish for ceremonies and festive occasions.

tips.vegetarian_options: Rare, use tofu or jackfruit as substitute

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Rendang, satu porsi'.

Rendang.fun_fact: Rendang has been listed by CNN Travel as one of the world’s most delicious foods.

Risoles.description: Risoles are fried rolls filled with vegetables, meat, or cheese.
Risoles.culture_events: Served at parties, gatherings, and as snack food.

tips.vegetarian_options: Yes, with only vegetables or cheese

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Risoles, satu porsi'.

Risoles.fun_fact: Risoles are inspired by Dutch croquettes but adapted to Indonesian tastes.

Sate.description: Sate (satay) is skewered and grilled meat served with peanut sauce or spicy sauce.
Sate.culture_events: Popular street food and traditional festival food.

tips.spice_level: Mild to medium depending on sauce

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Sate ayam, satu porsi'.

Sate.fun_fact: Satay is one of Indonesia's most iconic dishes and comes in hundreds of regional varieties.

Soto.description: Soto is a traditional Indonesian soup with meat, vegetables, and aromatic spices.
Soto.culture_events: Popular comfort food for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.

tips.spice_level: Mild to medium; sambal can be added
tips.vegetarian_options: Some versions with tofu or tempeh exist

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Soto ayam, satu porsi' (One portion of chicken soto).

Soto.fun_fact: Soto has hundreds of regional variations across Indonesia, each with unique spices and ingredients.

Telur Balado.description: Telur Balado is boiled eggs coated with spicy chili and tomato sauce.
Telur Balado.culture_events: Common side dish in Padang cuisine.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Telur Balado, satu porsi'.

Telur Balado.fun_fact: Balado is a traditional spicy chili paste used widely in Minang cuisine.

Telur Dadar.description: Telur Dadar is Indonesian omelette, often mixed with vegetables or spices.
Telur Dadar.culture_events: Eaten as breakfast or side dish.

tourist_notes.ordering: Say: 'Telur Dadar, satu porsi'.

Telur Dadar.fun_fact: Telur Dadar is simple but highly versatile; can include chilies, shallots, or herbs.
